data.source: Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI); government and media websites for social distancing measures
data.sample_size: 1,025 observations across 41 cities (≈25 daily observations per city)
data.access_details: CMI publicly available online; social-distancing dates compiled from official and media websites
data.notes: CMI reflects planned trips by users of the Citymapper app and excludes personal automobile navigation; results may not generalize to populations not using public transit.

method.description: The authors downloaded daily Citymapper Mobility Index data for 41 global cities between March 2 and March 26, 2020, recorded dates when governments implemented non-essential business closures (classified as moderate or intense), merged these policy data with the mobility series, and estimated the effect of time and social-distancing measures on mobility using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model.
steps: Download Citymapper Mobility Index data for each of the 41 cities covering March 2–26, 2020.
Collect implementation dates and intensity of governmental social-distancing measures from official and media sources.
Classify each city-day according to whether social-distancing measures were in place (none, moderate, intense).
Merge policy information with daily mobility observations to create a panel dataset (city × day).
Fit a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression with mobility as the outcome and predictors for calendar day (time) and social-distancing status, including random effects for cities.
Extract coefficients for daily trend and additional reduction associated with social-distancing measures and interpret results.
method.outcome_variable: Citymapper Mobility Index (percentage of baseline mobility)
method.independent_variables: Time (days since 2 March 2020); indicator for social-distancing measures (none vs. in place) and intensity classification
method.control_variables: Random intercepts for cities (no additional controls explicitly stated)

results.summary: Mobility across 41 cities declined sharply during March 2–26, 2020. On average, mobility fell by 3.4 % per day. After governments enacted social-distancing measures, mobility dropped by an additional 23 %, with no significant difference between moderate and intense closure categories.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Effect of social-distancing measures on mobility

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19 related social distancing measures and reduction in city mobility
